tweet: In short, the Trump Administration must be judicious as it develops options, and not let fast-moving events draw us into a wider conflict that threatens lives.

In the short term, American lives are at risk. In the long-term, we must not break our strategic relationship with the government of Iraq in a way that cedes Iraq to Iranian influence, or throws away the hard-fought gains we have made beating back ISIS.
That said, this is a moment for careful diplomacy. Our diplomats and service members in Iraq deserve a thoughtful, reasoned strategy to help de-escalate the situation.

The subsequent rocket attacks last week on a U.S. military location in Kirkuk, which killed a U.S. contractor and wounded several U.S. service members, demonstrate Iran's continued interest in using Iraqi proxies to attack the United States and further its regional objectives.

During the HASC congressional delegation to Iraq last month, we warned the government of Iraq about growing Iranian influence, and that the placement of Iranian ballistic missiles in Iraq, in particular, ran counter to ongoing U.S support to train and equip the Iraqi military.
The Iranian government has long sought political influence over the Iraqis, with the goal of using Iraq's territory to move people, materiel, and weapons across the Middle East.
As a former Shia militia CIA analyst who has served multiple times in Iraq, I have seen Iran's destabilizing activity in Iraq up close and personal.
No matter the politics, the government of Iraq has a responsibility to provide for the security of all foreign embassies on their soil. The government of Iraq must live up to those responsibilities.
I know how stressful this time must be for them and their families, and I was glad to hear that military reinforcements were ordered by the Secretary of Defense.
Two months ago, I traveled to Iraq on a bipartisan congressional delegation of the House Armed Services Committee and had the chance to spend time with the hardworking men and women at our Embassy.

It is difficult to watch the violent breach of the U.S. Embassy in Iraq earlier today.

I am thinking first and foremost of our diplomats and service members there, after having served three times in Iraq myself. https://bit.ly/39vZnae
We need to acknowledge the seriousness of this trend and understand the federal responsibility to take this just as seriously as foreign terrorism.
That is why I, along with other members of the Homeland Security Committee, have been urging the FBI and DHS to increase funding and staffing for domestic terrorism.

I will say it again: we are experiencing a rise in anti-semitic incidents both nation-wide and here in Michigan. 

It is dangerous and should give every one of us pause. https://bit.ly/37utJZh

The most common issue Michiganders raise with me isn't one ripped from the headlines—it's the one dominating our kitchen-table conversations: the price of prescription drugs. 

Yesterday, I was proud to vote for #HR3, a major bill to drive down drug costs: https://bit.ly/38AYhd3

Today we passed landmark legislation that would drive down the cost of prescription drugs by allowing our government to negotiate for the very best prices.

For the over 800,000 Michiganders with diabetes, #HR3 could bring down the price of insulin to as little as $400 a year. pic.twitter.com/J6h4lLxM8v

At a time when anti-Semitic attacks are on the rise, including in Michigan, no leader, of any party, should be trafficking in stereotypes that feed anti-Semitism. Especially the President or the United States.
He has a bad knack for trying to ingratiate himself to Jewish audiences while simultaneously using very old and very dangerous stereotypes.

This weekend President Trump made comments while speaking to a group of Jewish Americans that were bigoted and offensive. Unfortunately, this is not the first time we have heard comments like this from the President. https://bit.ly/2P6V0dI
.@DHSgov’s involvement in establishing this fraudulent university raises a number of serious questions, and I'll be following up to ensure they are answered.

I wrote a letter to the @DHSgov earlier this year asking for it to account for its involvement in the University of Farmington, a fraudulent university established by @ICEgov, that marketed a fictitious work-study program to foreign students.

Hundreds of foreign students who were enrolled in the University of Farmington have been arrested over the past year — students who were legitimately attempting to pursue a course of study and who were misled and taken advantage of for profit. https://bit.ly/2Rxc7a3
